mutualTLS: mTLS is required to make API calls. It can be requested to SIX via the Dev Portal.

get.description: REST API for End Of Day prices

parameters.name: scheme
parameters.description: Scheme of the Listing Identifier. It is a combination of the instrument scheme and the market scheme separated by underscore.

parameters.name: ids
parameters.description: Listing Identifier to be provided by client as input parameter. Several identifiers can be requested comma-separated.

An example request with ABB stock on the.description: An example request with ABB stock on the Swiss Market

parameters.name: preferredLanguage
parameters.description: Language in ISO 639 for string fields where content in different languages is available.

parameters.name: qualityOfService
parameters.description:
The up-to-dateness of price data, also referred to as 'Data Quality Timeliness' or 'License Quality,' is determined by the default priority when no specific quality is chosen by the client in their request. The available quality levels are delivered based on the following order:

    END_OF_DAY
    PREVIOUS_DAY

parameters.name: extensions
parameters.description: Select Extensions to know more about the GraphQL query, Data Status and Dataset IDs. EXPLAIN = include the equivalent GraphQL query in the REST API response.

items.description: Optional metadata to be returned in the response

api-version.description: The API version of the response

ratelimit-limit.description: The maximum number of requests in the current window

ratelimit-remaining.description: The number of requests remaining in the current rate limit window

retry-after.description: How long to wait before making a follow-up request (in seconds)

example.message: No required TLS certificate was sent

ratelimit-remaining.description: The number of requests remaining in the current rate limit window

retry-after.description: How long to wait before making a follow-up request (in seconds)

ratelimit-limit.description: The maximum number of requests in the current window

ratelimit-remaining.description: The number of requests remaining in the current rate limit window

retry-after.description: How long to wait before making a follow-up request (in seconds)

ratelimit-remaining.description: The number of requests remaining in the current rate limit window

retry-after.description: How long to wait before making a follow-up request (in seconds)

ratelimit-limit.description: The maximum number of requests in the current window

ratelimit-remaining.description: The number of requests remaining in the current rate limit window

retry-after.description: How long to wait before making a follow-up request (in seconds)

parameters.name: api-version
parameters.description: The API version is represented as a date in ISO 8601 format. If not explicitly specified, the system will default to the latest version available. Valid versions: 2022-01-01, 2023-01-01, 2024-01-01, 2024-03-01, 2024-06-01, 2024-08-01

code.description: code is used to identify the error

message.description: a human readable description of the error

ErrorDetail.description: A machine/human readable description of an error.

Explain.description: Exposes the internal GraphQL query details behind a given REST request. Could be useful to migrate from REST to GraphQL (e.g. to customize the shape of the response). Disabled by default.

Hint.description: a machine readable description of the error

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotAccruedInterestV.description: The Accrued interest refers to the interest that has accumulated on a fixed-income security but has not yet been paid to the investor. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotAnnualisedDivide.description: The Annualised Dividend is a calculated value that represents the total sum of distributions, including ordinary dividends and capital gains, made by an entity over the course of one year, retroactively from the ex-date 53 weeks back. It includes announced dividends by the management, providing insight into the entity's regular dividend distribution policy. However, special distributions and bonus dividends are excluded from this calculation. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotAuctionTheoretic.description:
The Auction Theoretical Matching Price, determined by the provider, is a price at which the maximum volume of orders can be executed at the time of an auction. The Theoretical Matching Price facilitates price discovery and transparency while helping resolve order imbalances. It shows at what price the trading would start if the order book was opened immediately.
Note that in some markets this price could be called Indicative Match Price, Equilibrium Price, etc. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotAverageDailyVolu.description: The Average Daily Volume Month To Date is determined by SIX based using day-end trading volume since the start of the current month. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotAverageDailyVolu.description: The Average Daily Volume Previous Month is determined by SIX based using day-end trading volume for the previous month.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotBreakEvenPointV1.description: The Break Even Point refers to the point at which the gains or losses from an investment or trade are equal to zero. It is the price or level of an asset at which there is neither profit nor loss. In other words, it is the point where the investor  has recouped their initial investment or reached a balance between costs and gains. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

size.description:
A Size associated with a price value represent an amount of units/contracts/nominal offered for sale, demanded for purchase, traded, orders that will be executed at a given price (e.g. in the event of an auction theoretical matching price quantity).

The size associated with a quote can directly signal the market participant the ability of the market to absorb their order. Furthermore, it provides an indication of a market imbalance. The Ask Size is required by traders trading data products and those entities interest in intra-day market data values.

The size associated with a trade allows a market participant to see the trade volumes and estimate or understand the impact of their own order on the market and the probability of getting it fully executed. In addition, the trade size allows calculation of the Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP).

timestamp.description:

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotCloseV1.description: The Close can either be derived from the final transaction conducted during the day or calculated by the provider. It serves as a reliable measure of the day's concluding value. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotCloseYearV1.description: The Close Year is the end of the year valuation price determined by SIX. Prices are selected by SIX at the last business day of the year. Subsequent updates valid for the preceding year and reported after 31 December are possible.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

size.description:
A Size associated with a price value represent an amount of units/contracts/nominal offered for sale, demanded for purchase, traded, orders that will be executed at a given price (e.g. in the event of an auction theoretical matching price quantity).

The size associated with a quote can directly signal the market participant the ability of the market to absorb their order. Furthermore, it provides an indication of a market imbalance. ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotClosingAskV1.description: The Closing Ask indicates the final/closing ask quote specifically identified as such by the provider (whether the exchange recognizes official closing values for quotes or not, i.e. some exchanges provide final quotes but do not official recognize them as official closing) or final quotes as determined by SIX based on the market practice. Generally, for contributors these will be the end of day quotes, while for exchanges it may be the quotes at the closing bell or at the end of the Trade at Last session. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

size.description:
A Size associated with a price value represent an amount of units/contracts/nominal offered for sale, demanded for purchase, traded, orders that will be executed at a given price (e.g. in the event of an auction theoretical matching price quantity).

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotClosingBidV1.description: The Closing Bid indicates the final/closing bid quote specifically identified as such by the provider (whether the exchange recognizes official closing values for quotes or not, i.e. some exchanges provide final quotes but do not official recognize them as official closing) or final quotes as determined by SIX based on the market practice. Generally, for contributors these will be the end of day quotes, while for exchanges it may be the quotes at the closing bell or at the end of the Trade at Last session. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotConvexityV1.description: The Convexity quantifies how the bond's price  deviates from the linear approximation of duration based on the time to maturity. Positive convexity means that as interest rates decrease, the bond's price increases at an increasing rate, while negative convexity implies that as rates increase, the bond's price decreases at an increasing rate. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotDeltaV1.description: The Delta is a measure of an option's sensitivity to changes in the price of the underlying asset. It indicates the expected change in the option price for every 1 currency unit change in the underlying asset. Delta helps traders and investors manage risk and create delta-neutral portfolios to mitigate exposure to price fluctuations. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotDividendYieldV1.description: A Dividend Yield is the annualized gross yield based on the market price of a share. The dividend amount paid is based on the actual historical regular dividend payments looking back 12 months (trailing dividend method).

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotDurationV1.description: The Duration represents the weighted average time (in years) it takes for an investor to receive the present value of the bond's cash flows, including coupon payments and the return of principal based on the time to maturity. Duration helps assess the price volatility and interest rate risk of fixed-income investments. Generally, higher-duration securities are more sensitive to interest rate changes, while lower-duration securities are less affected by interest rate movements. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

qualityOfService.description:
The up-to-dateness of price data, also referred to as 'Data Quality Timeliness' or 'License Quality', is determined by the default priority when no specific quality is chosen by the client in their request.
The available quality levels are delivered based on the following order:
1. REAL_TIME
2. DELAYED
3. END_OF_DAY
4. PREVIOUS_DAY

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotGammaV1.description: The Gamma is a measure of the rate of change in an option's delta in response to changes in the price of the underlying asset. It represents the acceleration of delta. A higher gamma indicates that the delta of an option will change more rapidly in response to small movements in the underlying asset's price, while a lower gamma implies slower changes in delta. Gamma is important for options traders as it helps them assess and manage the risk associated with changes in delta and underlying asset prices. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotGearingV1.description: The Gearing shows the ratio between the price of the underlying security and the price of the option. Also known as simple gearing. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotHighStaticLimitV.description: The High Static Limit is a provider or SIX calculated upper limit for price movements within a trading day. It is a static limit determined at the start of the trading day. Based on the high static limit market participants can estimate the price level for a possible volatility interruption and place their orders accordingly to profit from price spikes and price volatility. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

A Size associated with a price value represent an amount of units/contracts/nominal offered for sale, demanded for purchase, traded, orders that will be executed at a given price (e.g. in the event of an auction theoretical matching price quantity).

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotHighV1.description: A High is the highest traded price for the security within the current trading session. If not delivered by the price information provider and there is no recorded trade price, it may be computed using the highest ask of the trading session. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotHistoricalVolati.description: The Historical 180 Days Volatility refers to the measure of the price volatility of an underlying asset over a specific historical period of 180 days. It calculates the standard deviation of the asset's prices during that period to gauge the level of volatility experienced by the asset. Historical 180 Days Volatility provides a snapshot price fluctuations, allowing investors to assess the short-term volatility characteristics of the asset and make informed decisions based on the observed historical volatility patterns. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotHistoricalVolati.description: The Historical 250 Days Volatility refers to the measure of the price volatility of an underlying asset over a specific historical period of 250 days. It calculates the standard deviation of the asset's prices during that period to gauge the level of volatility experienced by the asset. Historical 180 Days Volatility provides a snapshot price fluctuations, allowing investors to assess the short-term volatility characteristics of the asset and make informed decisions based on the observed historical volatility patterns. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotHistoricalVolati.description: The Historical 30 Days Volatility refers to the measure of the price volatility of an underlying asset over a specific historical period of 30 days. It calculates the standard deviation of the asset's prices during that period to gauge the level of volatility experienced by the asset. Historical 30 Days Volatility provides a snapshot price fluctuations, allowing investors to assess the short-term volatility characteristics of the asset and make informed decisions based on the observed historical volatility patterns. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

Historical 90 Days Volatility provides a snapshot price fluctuations, allowing investors to assess the short-term volatility characteristics of the asset and make informed decisions based on the observed historical volatility patterns. value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotImpliedVolatilit.description: The Implied Volatility refers to the market's expectation of the future volatility of an underlying asset. It represents the level of uncertainty or anticipated price fluctuations that market participants believe the asset will experience over a specified period. Higher implied volatility suggests greater expected price swings, while lower implied volatility indicates a calmer or more stable market expectation. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotIndicatedAnnualD.description: The Indicated Annual Dividend is the amount of dividends per share a company or mutual fund is expected to pay. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotIntrinsicValueV1.description: The Intrinsic Value refers to the inherent value of an option or a security, independent of its market price. It represents tha actual worth of an option or security based on its underlying assets or cash flows. In the case of options, the intrinsic value is the difference between the current price of the underlying asset and the option's strike price, if it is in-the-money. If an option is out-of-the-money, the intrinsic value is zero. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotLatestDividendV1.description: The Latest Dividend is the distribution of corporate earnings to eligible shareholders. This field represents the cumulated distribution for the same ex-date. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

requestedId.description: The requested entity id used in the request

requestedScheme.description: The requested scheme used in the request

listingName.description:
Listing short name with up to 19 characters.
Deprecation reason: Use listingShortName, removed since version '2024-01-01'

marketName.description:
Market short name with up to 19 characters.
Deprecation reason: Use marketShortName, removed since version '2024-01-01'

listingShortName.description: Listing short name with up to 19 characters.

marketShortName.description: The market short name where the instrument is listed with up to 19 characters.

listingCurrency.description: The trading currency, as specified by SIX, typically follows the ISO 4217 alpha-3 code. This is shown in the main currency and not in fractional units. For cryptocurrencies, the Cryptocurrency Symbol in Instrument Symbology can be used for reference.

listingStatus.description: This shows the instruments status on the market - it shows if it is listed, suspended, admited to trading, delisted, etc

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotLowStaticLimitV1.description: The Low Static Limit is a provider or SIX calculated lower limit for price movements within a trading day. It is a static limit determined at the start of the trading day. Based on the low static limit market participants can estimate the price level for a possible volatility interruption and place their orders accordingly to profit from price spikes and price volatility. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

size.description:
A Size associated with a price value represent an amount of units/contracts/nominal offered for sale, demanded for purchase, traded, orders that will be executed at a given price (e.g. in the event of an auction theoretical matching price quantity).

The size associated with a quote can directly signal the market participant the ability of the market to absorb their order. Furthermore, it provides an indication of a market imbalance. The Ask Size is required by traders trading data products and those entities interest in intra-day market data values.

The size associated with a trade allows a market participant to see the trade volumes and estimate or understand the impact of their own order on the market and the probability of getting it fully executed. In addition, the trade size allows calculation of the Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP).

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotLowV1.description: A Low is the lowest traded price for the security within the current trading session. If not delivered by the price information provider and there is no recorded trade price, it may be computed using the lowest bid of the trading session. The Daily Low is a key input for charting. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotMarketCapitalisa.description: The Market Capitalisation refers to the total market value of a company's outstanding shares of stock.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotMidV1.description: The Mid is the arithmetical mean between the bid and ask price. If not provided by the price information provider, it is internally calcualted by SIX Financial Information. If no value is available for the current day, the value of the previous generation is delivered. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotModifiedDuration.description: The Modified Duration represents an adjusted version of the duration that takes into account the bond's yield-to-maturity. Modified duration quantifies the percentage change in the bond's price for a given change in yield based on the time to maturity. It helps investors assess the potential impact of interest rate fluctuations on bond prices and make informed decisions regarding fixed-income investments. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotMoneynessV1.description: The Moneyness refers to the relationship between the current price of an underlying asset and the strike price of an option. It indicates the percentage by which the strike price is above or below the current price of the underlying asset.  It shows if an option is in-the-money, at-the-money, or out-of-the-money. In-the-money options have a strike price favorable to the current price of the underlying asset, while out-of-the-money options have a strike price unfavorable to the current price. Moneyness is a crucial factor in options pricing and trading strategies. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotNumberOfTradesV1.description: The Number of Trades is the number of daily transactions during an exchange session. It indicates how many trades are made in a given instrument over a certain period of time. It helps to estimate the liquidity of the particular security and/or detect an unusual activity level on a listing. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotOmegaV1.description: The Omega represents the percentage change in an option's value with respect to the percentage change in the underlying price and measures the leverage of an options position. A measure for assessing the leverage of options and/or warrants. It indicates the percentage by which the price of a call (put) will increase (decrease) if the price of the underlying security rises by one percent. Also known as effective gearing. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotOpenInterestV1.description: The Open Interest is an amount of open Exchange Traded Derivative contracts that are not closed or delivered on a particular day. It indicates the activity of the derivative contracts. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

size.description:
A Size associated with a price value represent an amount of units/contracts/nominal offered for sale, demanded for purchase, traded, orders that will be executed at a given price (e.g. in the event of an auction theoretical matching price quantity).

The size associated with a quote can directly signal the market participant the ability of the market to absorb their order. Furthermore, it provides an indication of a market imbalance. The Ask Size is required by traders trading data products and those entities interest in intra-day market data values.

The size associated with a trade allows a market participant to see the trade volumes and estimate or understand the impact of their own order on the market and the probability of getting it fully executed. In addition, the trade size allows calculation of the Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP).

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotOpenV1.description: An Open Price is associated with the first transaction of the trade day. If not provided explicitly from a price information provider it is the first trade of the day immediately after the opening auction is completed. If there is no opening auction this will be the first trade of the day during the regular trading session. It is not necessarily a transacted price. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotPriceEarningsRat.description: The Price Earnings Ratio Estimated is the relationship of the share price to the net profit of the company. It is calculated by dividing the market price of the shares by the estimated earnings per share.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotPriceEarningsRat.description: The Price Earnings Ratio Reported is the relationship of the share price to the net profit of the company. It is calculated by dividing the market price of the shares by the reported earnings per share.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotRhoV1.description: The Rho is a measure of the sensitivity of an option's price to changes in interest rates. It represents the expected change in the option price for a 1% change in the risk-free interest rate. Rho is important for options traders and investors as it helps them evaluate the impact of interest rate fluctuations on option prices and make informed decisions regarding their options portfolio. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotSettlementPriceV.description: The Settlement Price is the price at which all the open Exchange Traded Derivative contracts are settled in cash on the given day. Typically, the settlement price is set by determining the weighted average price over a certain period of trading, typically shortly before the close of the market for Options, Futures and Indices. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotThetaV1.description: The Theta is a measure of the time decay of an option's value. It represents the rate at which an option's price decreases as time passes, assuming all other factors remain constant. Theta is particularly relevant for options traders and investors as it highlights the diminishing value of an option as it approaches its expiration date. A higher theta implies faster time decay, while a lower theta suggests slower erosion of an option's value over time. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotTimeToMaturityV1.description: The Time To Maturity refers to the remaining length from present day until a financial instrument, such as a bond (in years) or a derivative (in days), reaches its maturity date. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotTotalExpenseRati.description: The Total Expense Ratio is a measure used in the financial industry to assess the total cost associated with managing and operating an investment fund, such as a mutual fund or exchange-traded fund (ETF). It represents the percentage of a fund's total assets that is used to cover the expenses incurred in managing the fund, including management fees, administrative costs, custody fees, legal and audit fees, and other operational expenses. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotTurnoverTotalV1.description: Turnover Total is the cumulative turnover on- and off-exchange. This is calculated using volume in units/nominal/contracts multiplied by the current price of each traded unit. If no value is available for the current day, the value of the previous generation is delivered. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotTurnoverV1.description: Turnover is the total on-exchange amount traded in the security's currency. This is calculated using volume in units/nominal/contracts multiplied by the current price of each traded unit. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotVegaV1.description: The Vega is a measure of an option's sensitivity to changes in implied volatility. It represents the expected change in the option price for a 1% change in the implied volatility of the underlying asset. Vega is used by traders and investors to assess and manage the impact of volatility fluctuations on option prices, as higher volatility typically leads to increased option premiums and vice versa. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotVolumeTotalV1.description: Volume Total is the number of securities traded within the trading session. It shows the volume of securities which were traded on- and off-exchange (both on- and off-book). If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotVolumeV1.description: Volume is the number of securities traded within the trading session.  It only shows the volume of securities which were traded on-exchange (both on- and off-book). If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotVwapV1.description: The Volume Weighted Average Price (VWAP) is a trading indicator, which averages the ratio between the traded prices and the cumulative traded volume throughout the day.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Market data entry time - the time when the price was entered on a trader's side.
Transaction time - the time when the price was recognized by the exchange.
Exchange processing time - the time when the price was processed for updates, calculations at the exchange.
Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotYieldToCallV1.description: The Yield to Call is a financial metric that represents the total return an investor would receive if a callable bond is called or redeemed by the issuer before its scheduled maturity date. It is calculated by considering the bond's current market price, the call price, the remaining time to the call date, and the bond's coupon rate. Exclusively for bonds whose early redemption is expressly possible. Calculation only carried out if the invoice rate is greater than the redemption rate. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.

value.description: The Value of the price type.

timestamp.description:
Generally, in real-time feeds, the providers disseminate various Timestamps that are associated with different price types or events. There could be multiple timestamps associated with a given price.

Different providers may have different names for these timestamps and will not necessarily provide all of them in their feeds. In some cases, if the timestamp is not provided by the exchange, SIX internal timestamp may be used.

In SIX products only one timestamp can be displayed with a given price or event. If the exchange provides multiple timestamps within the feed, use the timestamps in the following priority:

Exchange's sending time - the time that the exchange disseminate the price via the feed.

ListingsEndOfDaySnapshotYieldToMaturityV.description: A Yield to Maturity is the internal rate of return (IRR, overall interest rate) earned by the investor who buys the bond today at the market price, assuming that the bond will be held until maturity, and that all coupon and principal payments will be made on schedule. If the market is not yet closed or/and the embargo time has not yet elapsed, the previous generation value is provided.
